CONTRACTING_BODY.CA_TYPE_OTHER: Public foundation established under German private law

SHORT_DESCR.P: The Academy of European Law (ERA) invites expressions of interest in tendering for the redevelopment of its web presence www.era.int
The call for tenders will consist of 3 lots:
— Lot 1: Website and online shop,
— Lot 2: Offline access solution,
— Lot 3: Learning management system.
The fundamental characteristics of ERA’s new web presence will be:
— simple, responsive and accessible design,
— content-focused and dynamic structure,
— customised user experience,
— multilingual content,
— 1 login only for all services (MyERA),
— multiple output channels for the same content.

Expressions of interest are welcome from a single supplier (for one or more lots) or from a consortium of suppliers (for at least 2 lots). Interoperability will be one of the selection criteria, so the more lots covered by a tender, the more likely it is to succeed. Expressions of interest and tenders may be submitted in either English or German.

The main objectives of ERA's website and online shop should be to present users with the ERA programme offer best suited to their requirements, to convince them of its benefits and to enable them to access, register for or purchase it with as much ease as possible.
ERA’s web presence should be a source of information about its own programmes and of content about EU law to which users will want to return regularly.
It should serve as a platform for participants to access training resources.
It should explain ERA and its activities to users who do not already know it and to potential new clients and supporters.
Key functional requirements:
— design: simple, responsive, e-accessible, compliant with ERA’s corporate identity and based on flexible templates allowing for variations and development,
— user-friendly navigation structure focused on ever-changing product range,
— page structures that allow for multiple language versions of each page,
— page types: start page, standard pages and product pages (drawing on regularly changing data from ERA’s internal database),
— content blocks that can be placed flexibly in pages to deliver the main functions (e.g. login interface, search tool, media, forms, lists, text…),
— option to create subsites with the same or similar functions to the main site,
— search and filter tools,
— content management solution: imports core product data from ERA’s internal database, allows for it to be edited and supplemented, centrally stores media, and exports content to different channels,
— user profiles: simple (mailing subscription only) or full “MyERA”, linked to ERA’s internal database, allowing users to make transactions and access content,
— product types and subtypes: determine how products are displayed,
— transaction types: determine how products are handled and when access to content is provided,

— online shop: based on shopping basket system, users should be able to order for themselves and for third parties and to access their order history; shop should be capable of handling standard discounts and discount voucher codes; payment should be possible on receipt of invoice, by PayPal or by credit card.

INFO_ADD.P: All lots must fulfil certain transversal functional requirements (user tracking, data protection), operating conditions and project management standards, which are described in the procurement documents.

SHORT_DESCR.P: ERA would like to offer a mobile solution that offers its customers the possibility to view their user profile, access resources or use e-learning applications offline.
Key functional requirements:
— should provide offline access to user profile, order history and online content, e.g. e-learning products, seminar documentation,
— should require the user to create a full MyERA account on the website and should synchronise user data and order history with the account whenever online,
— compatible with the learning management system in order to deliver e-learning content.

INFO_ADD.P: All lots must fulfil certain transversal functional requirements (user tracking, data protection), operating conditions and project management standards, which are described in the procurement documents.

SHORT_DESCR.P: ERA’s current e-learning platform is a separate, Moodle-based course management system developed and hosted in-house and connected to the website via an improvised single sign-on procedure. ERA would like to achieve a seamless integration of its e-learning content in its new web presence.
Key functional requirements:
— course content should be linked from the product page on the website,
— single sign-on for website and learning management system (LMS),
— communication of learning progress from the LMS to MyERA,
— content developed with third party authoring systems (e.g. Articulate Storyline) should be fully implementable in the LMS,
— SCORM, AICC and TinCan API compatibility to import and exchange learning items,
— detailed user statistics and test results, including time spent using product,
— direct communication tools: e.g. blog, chat, forum; with option to embed in a page of the main website.

INFO_ADD.P: All lots must fulfil certain transversal functional requirements (user tracking, data protection), operating conditions and project management standards, which are described in the procurement documents.

ECONOMIC_FINANCIAL_INFO.P: In order to be invited to to submit a Tender in response to the detailed Call for Tenders, Suppliers must fulfil certain minimum qualification criteria.

ECONOMIC_FINANCIAL_MIN_LEVEL.P: The supplier(s) must have experience of managing web, app or e-learning development projects within the last 2 years with an individual value exceeding EUR 100 000.

TECHNICAL_PROFESSIONAL_INFO.P: In order to be invited to to submit a Tender in response to the detailed Call for Tenders, Suppliers must fulfil certain minimum qualification criteria.

TECHNICAL_PROFESSIONAL_MIN_LEVEL.P: The supplier(s) must have enough members of appropriately qualified, permanent staff to complete all deliverables within the agreed timeframe, including allowing reasonable time for testing and implementing change requests. The Supplier must have a contingency plan to replace staff members by persons with equivalent qualifications and experience in the event of illness or any other reason for being unable to complete the deliverable.
The members of the supplier(s)’s staff working on the project must have experience of developing multilingual web applications.
For Lot 1, staff members must also have experience of developing e-commerce solutions.
For Lot 2, staff members must also have experience of developing apps.
For Lot 3, staff members must also have experience of developing learning management systems.
The supplier(s) must be able to guarantee updates/support for a minimum period of 5 years from the start of development for any 3rd-party dependencies or components it uses.
The supplier(s) must be able to demonstrate that the quality of its code and documentation is sufficient to allow 3rd-party changes after launch.

INFO_ADD.P: Tenderers must submit a European Single Procurement Document with their Expression of Interest. Templates in English and German are available at www.era.int/?127797&en
